title: Late Ottoman Palestinians: Social and Cultural Dynamics in an Eastern Mediterranean Society during the Age of Empire, 1880-1920
descriptions: This project explores the social and cultural dynamics of late Ottoman Palestine during the transformative period from 1880 to 1920, a time marked by imperialism, globalization, and Ottoman state-building. By focusing on individual and collective coping strategies employed by Palestinians across ethnic, religious, and class lines, the research aims to uncover the mechanisms through which social formations emerged and evolved. Central to this investigation is the analysis of census-taking as a social process, which will provide crucial data for understanding how individuals and communities navigated the challenges of the era, such as economic stress and social mobility. The project will establish methodological standards for comparative social and cultural history, contributing to the broader effort to write a global history of the period. By developing a theoretical framework and utilizing census data, the research will set new benchmarks for Historical Geographic Information Systems (HGIS) studies of the Ottoman Empire. Additionally, the project will offer new insights into the study of colonialism, particularly during the British Mandate, by enabling comparisons with other historical sources.

**Description:**

In the Eastern Mediterranean, the four decades between 1880 and 1920 were a time of imperialism, globalisation and Ottoman state building, but also of profound social differentiation, fuelled by an unprecedented degree of human mobility and migration. Therefore, in this period we find the roots of many social formations that have remained relevant until the present. My focus is on the individual and collective practices for coping with various challenges and on census-taking as a social process. It will open up new perspectives on social and cultural dynamics in late Ottoman Palestine, in a historical context defined by European imperialism, Ottoman state building and globalisation.
